segment.source: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V
segment.target: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V

segment.source: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V
segment.target: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V

segment.source: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V
segment.target: How to Convert a Package Created in a Previous Version of App-V

segment.source: You can use the package converter utility to upgrade virtual application packages that have been created with previous versions of App-V.
segment.target: You can use the package converter utility to upgrade virtual application packages that have been created with previous versions of App-V.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you are running a computer with a 64-bit architecture, you must use the x86 version of PowerShell.
segment.target: If you are running a computer with a 64-bit architecture, you must use the x86 version of PowerShell.

segment.source: The package converter can only directly convert packages that were created by using the App-V 4.5 sequencer or a subsequent version.
segment.target: The package converter can only directly convert packages that were created by using the App-V 4.5 sequencer or a subsequent version.

segment.source: Packages that were created using a version prior to App-V 4.5 must be upgraded to the App-V 4.5 or App-V 4.6 format before conversion.
segment.target: Packages that were created using a version prior to App-V 4.5 must be upgraded to the App-V 4.5 or App-V 4.6 format before conversion.

segment.source: The following information provides direction for converting existing virtual application packages.
segment.target: The following information provides direction for converting existing virtual application packages.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must configure the package converter to always save the package ingredients file to a secure location and directory.
segment.target: You must configure the package converter to always save the package ingredients file to a secure location and directory.

segment.source: A secure location is accessible only by an administrator.
segment.target: A secure location is accessible only by an administrator.

segment.source: Additionally, when you deploy the package, you should save the package to a location that is secure, or make sure that no other user is allowed to be logged in during the conversion process.
segment.target: Additionally, when you deploy the package, you should save the package to a location that is secure, or make sure that no other user is allowed to be logged in during the conversion process.

segment.source: Getting started
segment.target: Getting started

segment.source: Install the App-V Sequencer on a computer in your environment.
segment.target: Install the App-V Sequencer on a computer in your environment.

segment.source: For information about how to install the Sequencer, see How to Install the Sequencer.
segment.target: For information about how to install the Sequencer, see How to Install the Sequencer.

segment.source: The following cmdlets are available:
segment.target: The following cmdlets are available:

segment.source: Test-AppvLegacyPackage – This cmdlet is designed to check packages.
segment.target: Test-AppvLegacyPackage – This cmdlet is designed to check packages.

segment.source: It will return information about any failures with the package such as missing .sft files, an invalid source, .osd file errors, or invalid package version.
segment.target: It will return information about any failures with the package such as missing .sft files, an invalid source, .osd file errors, or invalid package version.

segment.source: This cmdlet will not parse the .sft file or do any in depth validation.
segment.target: This cmdlet will not parse the .sft file or do any in depth validation.

segment.source: For information about options and basic functionality for this cmdlet, using the PowerShell cmdline, type .
segment.target: For information about options and basic functionality for this cmdlet, using the PowerShell cmdline, type .

segment.source: ConvertFrom-AppvLegacyPackage – To convert an existing package, type .
segment.target: ConvertFrom-AppvLegacyPackage – To convert an existing package, type .

segment.source: In this command, represents the location of the existing package and is the output directory to which the resulting App-V 5.0 virtual application package file will be saved.
segment.target: In this command, represents the location of the existing package and is the output directory to which the resulting App-V 5.0 virtual application package file will be saved.

segment.source: By default, if you do not specify a new name, the old package name will be used for the App-V 5.0 filename.
segment.target: By default, if you do not specify a new name, the old package name will be used for the App-V 5.0 filename.

segment.source: Additionally, the package converter optimizes performance of packages in App-V 5.0 by setting the package to stream fault the App-V package.
segment.target: Additionally, the package converter optimizes performance of packages in App-V 5.0 by setting the package to stream fault the App-V package.

segment.source: This is more performant than the primary feature block and fully downloading the package.
segment.target: This is more performant than the primary feature block and fully downloading the package.

segment.source: The flag DownloadFullPackageOnFirstLaunch allows you to convert the package and set the package to be fully downloaded by default.
segment.target: The flag DownloadFullPackageOnFirstLaunch allows you to convert the package and set the package to be fully downloaded by default.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Before you specify the output directory, you must create the output directory.
segment.target: Before you specify the output directory, you must create the output directory.

segment.source: Advanced Conversion Tips
segment.target: Advanced Conversion Tips

segment.source: Piping - PowerShell supports piping.
segment.target: Piping - PowerShell supports piping.

segment.source: Piping allows you to call .
segment.target: Piping allows you to call .

segment.source: In this example, the directory object that represents will be given as input to the command and bound to the parameter.
segment.target: In this example, the directory object that represents will be given as input to the command and bound to the parameter.

segment.source: Piping like this is especially useful when you want to batch commands together; for example, .
segment.target: Piping like this is especially useful when you want to batch commands together; for example, .

segment.source: This piped command would test the packages and then pass those objects on to actually be converted.
segment.target: This piped command would test the packages and then pass those objects on to actually be converted.

segment.source: You can also apply a filter on packages without errors or only specify a directory which contains an .sprj file or pipe them to another cmdlet that adds the filtered package to the server or publishes them to the App-V 5.0 client.
segment.target: You can also apply a filter on packages without errors or only specify a directory which contains an .sprj file or pipe them to another cmdlet that adds the filtered package to the server or publishes them to the App-V 5.0 client.

segment.source: Batching - The PowerShell command enables batching.
segment.target: Batching - The PowerShell command enables batching.

segment.source: More specifically, the cmdlets support taking a string object for the parameter which represents a list of directory paths.
segment.target: More specifically, the cmdlets support taking a string object for the parameter which represents a list of directory paths.

segment.source: This allows you to enter and then call or to use piping and call .
segment.target: This allows you to enter and then call or to use piping and call .

segment.source: Other functionality - PowerShell has other built-in functionality for features such as aliases, piping, lazy-binding, .NET object, and many others.
segment.target: Other functionality - PowerShell has other built-in functionality for features such as aliases, piping, lazy-binding, .NET object, and many others.

segment.source: All of these are usable in PowerShell and can help you create advanced scenarios for the Package Converter.
segment.target: All of these are usable in PowerShell and can help you create advanced scenarios for the Package Converter.
